summary: This is a legal commentary article by Evan T. Barr analyzing U.S. Attorney Geoffrey Berman's public statements criticizing Prince Andrew's failure to cooperate in the Jeffrey Epstein sex-trafficking investigation. The article examines whether Berman's remarks violated DOJ guidelines on commenting on ongoing investigations and discusses the legal challenges Prince Andrew faces.

persons.name: Evan T. Barr
persons.role: Author, former federal prosecutor, partner at Fried Frank Harris Shriver & Jacobsen
persons.context: Author of the article analyzing the legal implications of U.S. Attorney Berman's public statements about Prince Andrew's lack of cooperation. He previously worked on a matter for Epstein at another law firm.

persons.name: Geoffrey Berman
persons.role: U.S. Attorney for the Southern District of New York

persons.name: Prince Andrew

keyFacts: U.S. Attorney Geoffrey Berman made unusual public statements criticizing Prince Andrew for failing to cooperate with the Epstein sex-trafficking investigation, departing from standard DOJ practice of not commenting on ongoing investigations.

Prince Andrew gave a controversial BBC interview in November 2019 where he denied Virginia Roberts Giuffre's allegations but acknowledged friendships with Epstein and Ghislaine Maxwell, after which he stepped back from royal duties.
The article analyzes whether Berman's comments violated DOJ regulations (28 C.F.R. ยง50.2) and the U.S. Attorney's Manual, particularly regarding comments about a subject's refusal to cooperate.

Prince Andrew faces significant legal pressure, including potential use of mutual legal assistance treaties (MLAT) to obtain his testimony and risks of perjury charges if he testifies inconsistently with his BBC interview statements.
Author Evan T. Barr reveals he previously worked on a legal matter for Jeffrey Epstein while employed at another law firm.
